awd_titl_txt: CC* Planning: Developing a Plan to Improve Research Computing at Christopher Newport University
awd_abstract_narration:
The aims of this project are to develop and publish a five-year cyberinfrastructure plan for scientific computing at Christopher Newport University (CNU). The past decade has seen CNU dramatically increase its research capabilities and impact, however the computing resources used are often not accessible to the wider campus. A unified computing plan, which includes the creation of a scientific computing cluster, is needed to support CNU’s research programs and to provide resources to faculty across the university. In collaboration with IT services, we are identifying the computing resources necessary to meet research needs and estimating the infrastructure required to support those resources. The end goal of this project is to develop a plan for comprehensive scientific computing infrastructure at CNU that will support existing research, enable researchers to expand into new fields, and allow CNU to contribute to national cyberinfrastructure by providing new resources to the Open Science Grid.  
 
CNU is a primarily undergraduate institution that has a significant focus on student involvement in research. Research areas that are heavy users of computational resources include experimental nuclear physics, gravitational wave astronomy, natural language processing, other applications of artificial intelligence to data science, and mathematical simulation.
Through the improved cyberinfrastructure supported by this work, students will have significantly improved opportunities to engage in research that both expands the forefront of our understanding of science and explores the use of emerging technologies. Women and underrepresented students are specifically supported and encouraged to engage in these research opportunities through several CNU's initiatives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award successfully advanced research computing at Christopher Newport University (CNU), a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI) in Newport News, Virginia. The project’s main outcome was the development of a comprehensive Campus Cyberinfrastructure Plan to guide future investments in computational resources, enabling faculty and students to engage in cutting-edge research and education.

As a direct result of this award, a GPU server (NVIDIA A100) was purchased, installed, and commissioned as a prototype for a larger computing cluster. This server has already supported resource-intensive research projects in Natural Language Processing (NLP), nuclear physics, and astrophysics. These advances reduced researchers’ dependence on external resources, enhanced efficiency, and allowed new scientific areas to be explored.

The project also prioritized understanding the current and future computational needs of the campus. Through biweekly meetings with CNU’s Chief Information Officer (CIO) and IT Services, the team assessed data center capacities, developed protocols for system administration, and identified funding opportunities for personnel and hardware. These efforts culminated in a successful CC* Compute-Campus proposal submission, with plans to integrate 20% of the future cluster’s capacity into the Open Science Grid (OSG), benefiting national research efforts.

In terms of human resource development, the project trained IT staff in research computing and security, while students gained valuable experience in system administration and research using advanced computing technologies. These outcomes contributed to a more skilled and diverse STEM workforce at CNU and beyond.

Overall, this award established the foundation for a sustainable research computing ecosystem at CNU, enhancing campus infrastructure, supporting innovative research, and preparing students and staff for leadership in computational science and technology.

Modified by: William Phelps
